Baseline: Israel is a relatively young country being founded in 1948 and the presidents have been in office for 4-12 years with Netanyahu being the longest serving president. There is no limit to how many terms a president can serve. Criminal corruption charges are not legally enough for him to have to cease to be prime minister and with delayed proceedings not likely to happen before January 2021  (https://www.timesofisrael.com/netanyahus-lawyers-buy-more-time-to-respond-to-charges-likely-delaying-trial/). The 17th of May 2023 is the latest possible date for an election. However, early elections can be called by a vote of the majority of Knesset members, or by an edict of the President, and normally occur on occasions of political stalemate and of the inability of the government to get the parliament's support for its policies. This has happened often.  Probability of early elections called by majority vote in Knesset:
- The Likud party holds the most seats so not likely that they would force election before the 1st of January 2021. However, due to ignorance I am guessing at least a 4% chance due to someone really wanting to get him from his own party or two or more parties join forces. The trial is a factor that impact governments ability to support policies, however, I see this a less important than the average power fights in politics.   Probability of edict by president:
- As the longest serving president and based on how he is fighting to stay in power I would rate this as 0% in the given time period
- Given his age I rate the likelihood of health issues as 2% based on death rates with men in his age

The bill, proposed by Derech Eretz MK Zvi Hauser, must pass two more readings before it becomes law, but its future is uncertain, as Likud has not yet committed to supporting it in its second and third readings. The deadline for the budget is August 25. Under the terms of the bill, that limit would be put off by 100 days until December 3. I did a little more research on this one and am lowering my forecast as a result. I think a conviction is a near certainty for reasons stated in my last post.   Yet, Israel has never had to deal with a prime minister convicted of corruption while in office.  The only other prime minister accused of corruption resigned before indictment.  Also, all other ministers indicted of corruption either resigned or were fired.   The Israeli Supreme Court has ordered the removal of other elected offices for conviction of lesser crimes but Netanyahu's situation is unique.  In my initial research I found an article that said a Knesset member must resign all cabinet positions when indicted pursuant to Israel’s basic law.    After making a post, I had a reply (a while back, which I did not have time to respond to) asking if an Israeli prime minister had to resign if convicted and how long an appeal would last.  I tried to find the original article mentioned above but could not.  I think it was on the Haaretz website.   Unfortunately, I have used up my free articles, and they want me to buy a $120/year subscription that I am not willing to purchase just to answer this question.   Regrettably, The Times of Israel, Jpost, I24news and the other English language Israeli news websites were not nearly as helpful. 
In any event, I did save one very insightful Haaretz article.  In that article and several Wikipedia articles, I learned some very important new facts.
Israel has something called basic law.  It was enacted in pieces over several decades.  From the Haaretz website Article 18 states: “18. (a) Should the Prime Minister be convicted of an offense which the court defined as involving moral turpitude, the Knesset may remove him from office, pursuant to a decision of a majority of the Knesset members. Should the Knesset so decide, the Government shall be deemed to have resigned.
(b) Within 30 days of the verdict becoming final [this is an error in translation. The Hebrew text does not include the words “becoming final” – EC], the Knesset Committee of the Knesset will render its decision regarding its recommendation pertaining to the removal of the Prime Minister from office, and shall present its recommendation to the Knesset plenum; should the committee fail to bring its recommendation to the plenum during the prescribed period, the Speaker will raise the issue in the Knesset plenum.
[…]
(d) Should the Knesset decide not to remove the Prime Minister from office, and should the verdict as per section (a) above become final, the Prime Minister will cease to serve in office and the Government shall be deemed to have resigned. [end.]” On its face, it appears that Netanyahu must be removed upon a “final” conviction.  A conviction is final under Israeli law when the time for appeal has passed and no appeal was filed or when the appeals process has run its course.    The only conviction of an Israeli prime minister involved Ehud Olmert.  He resigned as prime minister about 30 days before being served with the indictment.   He was convicted, and his appeals lasted seven (7) years.  Yet, he remained as interim prime minister until a replacement prime minister was sworn in.  The corruption charges Netanyahu faces—bribery, fraud and breach of trust—were considered crimes of moral turpitude sufficient to remove other ministers and officials.  A conviction was not required for the Israeli Supreme Court to order the removal of lesser minsters. Specifically, the Israeli Supreme Court ordered Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin to fire two ministers in 1993 for corruption after indictment but before conviction. The Court noted that there was no statute that required a prime minister to fire these ministers but held that the basic law set minimum standards for serving in public office and did not exhaust the reasons for which a minister may be required to resign.   Further, the court held that failure to fire these ministers would undermine public confidence in government.  According to Haaretz, the court further held, “that the presumption of innocence does not preclude the removal of public officials based on reliable administrative evidence of criminal wrongdoing that is directly connected to their service in public office. According to the court, a criminal indictment imputing serious offenses to a public official would suffice for removal.” Interestingly, the Israeli Supreme Court on May 6, 2020, found that Netanyahu was not required to resign for mere indictment like other ministers had.  A corrupt minister can return to public life if elected to the Knesset after conviction. Specifically, there is the interesting case of Aryeh Deri, the minister of the interior, who Yitzhak Rabin fired for corruption, who was convicted of corruption in 2000, and who was reelected to the Knesset in 2013.   He served again as minister of the interior in 2016, and briefly in other positions including minister of the economy and minister for religious services.  He was forced out a second time due to new corruption charges.    The Deri and Olmert cases make clear that even if Netanyahu is convicted he can remain until 1) his appeals are exhausted (7 years for Olmert); 2) a new prime minister is appointed (as did Olmert); 3) and, he can return to public life if re-elected after conviction .   In theory, he be interim prime minister until he was reelected as the new prime minister.  Thus, he could be the new prime minister replacing himself. The Supreme Court could still order him removed as it did with other ministers despite Article 18.  As stated above, they did order Yitzak Rabin to fire two ministers despite the lack of statutory authority.  The most likely scenario, I think, is that he was convicted but filed an appeal, which lasted until after this question has closed.      I think there is a 40-60 chance however that he could be forced to resign or the Supreme Court could remove him as a result of his conviction on these charges.  I believe this will happen shortly after conviction (say within a month) or not at all.

At this point, this question has been largely replaced by the question: Will Netanyahu be convicted in his trial this month of serious political corruption? He goes to trial on May 23, 2020, in the District Court in Israel.  The court does not have juries.  It uses a mixture of an adversarial system and an inquisitorial system (where judges, not lawyers, ask questions.)   Therefore, his popularity as shown in the public opinion polls will have much less effect on the outcome since there will be no jury. The post-trial conviction rate in Israeli criminal courts is about 93 percent.  That is stunning.  I did some research and found a number of cases were Israeli ministers were convicted of corruption on Wikipedia.   Part of the reason is the vast majority of criminal cases are dismissed prior to trail.  Thus, it seems only cases with merit go forward.   I cannot imagine a prosecutor in Israel taking a case to trial against a sitting prime minister without a near perfect case.  I am a former criminal lawyer, and if the prosecutors office in Israel is like prosecutors offices  in the United States, losing  this case could easily end a career.  Therefore, I suspect the baseline of 93 percent should be increased a bit.  Also, Netanyahu has four criminal cases against him.  (There is a fifth to be tried at the same time, but Netanyahu is not charged.)   Netanyahu has also admitted the facts of these cases to be true.  He is arguing that he did not have the criminal intent.  For example, Netanyahu admitted receiving just under $200,000.00 in very expensive wine, cigars and jewelry (for his wife), and he did help the donor with an American visa, tax breaks and regulations in Isreal.  Netanyahu just said there was no quid pro quo.   Finally, in his negotiations to create the new government, he had been insisting on permanent immunity from prosecution.  Thus, he seems worried.  I do not know who the specific judges are and their backgrounds.  I also do not know anything about the prosecutors.   Finally, Netanyahu is going to trial in the District Court.  He will have the right to appeal to the Supreme Court.  Rarely is a new trial granted or a conviction overturned in Israel.  However, I do not know how long this will take, and whether Netanyahu can remain prime minister while the appeal goes forward.  All in all it is not looking good for  Netanyahu. https://www.haaretz.com/1.4950727

Israelis are going to the polls today for their third parliamentary election in less than a year. The two elections held in 2019 failed to yield a clear winner with the embattled prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, losing his coalition’s majority. However his challenger, Benny Gantz, failed to cobble together a coalition of his own due to political fragmentation among the opposition. Mr Netanyahu, facing multiple indictments of corruption and a trial date in just two weeks, has launched a ferocious smear campaign against his challenger, including sexual innuendo and unwarranted jibes about his mental health. The polls show a slight swing towards his Likud party, but not enough to win a majority and break the political deadlock.

Legislative elections for the 23rd Knesset will be held in Israel on 2 March 2020. Early elections were called because of on 11 December 2019 because of continued failure by all parties to form the country's next government. The extended period of political deadlock that led up to the election was the result of close races in April and September 2019 that left both incumbent Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and opposition leader Benny Gantz unable to muster a 61-seat governing majority, in coalition with their respective blocs of smaller, ideologically-allied parties.
This is not a real good starting ground for Mr. Netanyahu, considering that since December 2016, Netanyahu has been under investigation for corruption by Israeli police and prosecutors. On 21 November 2019, he was indicted on charges of breach of trust, bribery, and fraud. Due to the indictment, Netanyahu is legally required to relinquish all of his ministry posts other than the prime minister position.
Meanwhile, the Knesset will discuss Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s request for parliamentary immunity from corruption charges on Thursday next week, the head of a key committee announced Tuesday. Blue and White MK Avi Nissenkorn, head of the Knesset’s Arrangements Committee, penciled on January 30 at 2:30 p.m. as the start of Netanyahu’s hearings.
Once formed, the House Committee could conceivably debate and potentially vote on Netanyahu’s immunity request in the coming weeks, ahead of election day. Even if it fails to reach a verdict by then, its meetings are likely to keep Netanyahu’s criminal proceedings front and center in the election campaign.

After two extremely close elections between Likud and the Blue and White Party, the interceding indictment of Bibi on serious corruption charges has come. With each election cycle, the Israeli voters have become more and more tired of Bibi's failing leadership and there is a growing, national yearning for change in Israel's populace. Now, the resentments of the non-haredi majority have  also begun to manifest themself in the election fatigue and the Bibi fatigue. Blue and White clarly appeals to those who suffer from Bibi fatigue, but also want a strong PM  with a military past. The possibility that Blue and White can win 61 votes in Parliament without a coalition with another party is still slim, but not impossible. The fact that the overwhelming majority of the Israeli population, which is NOT ultra Orthodox, feels betrayed by Bibi and is tired of the growing theocratic bent in Israeli government and daily life, combined with the growing popularity of another leader, Avigdor Lieberman, whose views on the growing theocratic tendency makes it likely the two of them can combine for more than 61 votes in the next parliament. Both are strong on national security. More important, the two in combination can present a strong front for Israel in next stage negotiation for a final solution, which will be a two state solution with the Palestinians. The growing fatigue with this interminable struggle bodes well for Blue and White to defeat Likud as well.

I think there are three ways this question could resolve “Yes”:
1. Netanyahu is removed from office by Parliamentary vote after losing his corruption trial
2. Netanyahu loses in upcoming elections
3. Netanyahu dies before the question is over I think the odds of 3 are very low. According to Israel’s actuarial tables, the probability of a 70 year old Jewish male dying in the next year is 2% (https://www.cbs.gov.il/he/publications/doclib/2019/1763/t05.pdf).  A quick search of the opinion polls suggest that the political stalemate in Israel is unlikely to be resolved in March. Beyond that it sounds like if a coalition can’t be formed then new elections are held 5 to 6 months later. That would suggest two opportunities (March and again in the Fall) for a resolution on these grounds. I put the odds of a resolution in March at 10% and later in the year at 20% which gives me a 28% chance.  If I assume the result of the election is 50/50 (given how close it is), that’d be an 14% probability.  Basic Law - essentially the constitution for Israel says that the Prime Minister can only be removed from office by a vote after all appeals are exhausted. While this may seem straightforward there is no precedent at the Prime Minister level. At lower minister levels, there is precedent saying that upon indictment, the minister should be removed from office. Either way, this would suggest a prolonged and complicated legal battle that would involve some allegations of the courts meddling in politics. Ultimately, I think the likelihood of a final court decision this year is low, about 15-20%.  Taking these three factors together (2+14+18) gives me 34%
